work.p: Most of the lines in this manuscript amount to a poetic rendering of sentences and phrases drawn from the prose preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass and constitute a partial draft of the 1856 poem "Poem of Many In One," which eventually became "By Blue Ontario's Shore." A majority of the manuscript lines appeared near the end of the published poem. These include, specifically, versions of the first several lines (through "Its deserts, forests, clearings, log houses, hunters, are you and me"), the line "The perpetual arrivals of immigrants are you and me" and the section of ten lines from "Natural and artificial are you and me" through "Not librety#8212;not to cheer up slawes and horrify despots." The lines "It's ships, whaling, gold-digging are you and me, / Its paved cities, wharves, wealth, avenues, dwellings, are you and me," and "The north, south, east, west, are you and me" were used, greatly altered, in a section of lines that appeared nearer the beginning of "Poem of Many in One."

The line at the bottom of this manuscript, partially cut away, was drawn from the prose preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass and was used in "Liberty Poem for Asia, Africa, Europe, America, Australia, Cuba, and the Archipelagoes of The Sea," published in the 1856 Leaves. Whitman titled the final version of the poem "To a Foil'd European Revolutionaire."

titleStmt.title: are you and me
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Most of the lines in this manuscript amount to a poetic rendering of sentences and phrases drawn from the prose preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass and constitute a partial draft of the 1856 poem "Poem of Many In One," which eventually became "By Blue Ontario's Shore." The line at the bottom of this manuscript, partially cut away, was also drawn from the 1855 preface but was used in the 1856 poem "Liberty Poem for Asia, Africa, Europe, America, Australia, Cuba, and the Archipelagoes of The Sea," which Whitman titled, in its final version, "To a Foil'd European Revolutionaire."

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: "Sanity and Ensemble" (ms. fragment) [on verso, unidentified ms. fragment], undated. 1 item (1 leaf)
bibl.orgName: Walt Whitman Collection, 1842–1957, Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
Draft lines on the back of this manuscript also relate to the preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass.

lg.l:
, the compact, peace,
are you and me,

del.l: The perpetual arrivals of immigrants are you and me,

lg.l:
The Its young men's manner's, speech, dress, friendships
are you and me,
The Its Crimes, enormities lies, defections, slavery, are you and me,

The Its Congress is you and me—the officers, capitols, armies,
ships, are you and me,
The Its inventions, science, shchools, are you and me,
The Its deserts, forests, clearings, settlements, log houses, hunters, are you and me,

add.l: Its ships, fisheries, whaling, gold‑digging are you and me,

lg.l:
The Its paved cities, wharves, wealth, avenues, dwellings,
are you and me.

add.l: The perpetual arrivals of immigrants are you and me.

lg.l: The north, south, east, west, are you and me,
Natural and artificial are you and me,
Liberty, language, poems, employments, are you and me,
Failures, successes, births, deaths, are you and me,
Past, presteent, future, are only you and me.—
I swear I will am cannot to evade any part of myself,
Not America, nor any attribute of America,
Not my body—not friendship, hospitality, procreation,
Not my soul—not the last explanation of prudence,

add.l: Not faith, sin, defiance, nor any of the dispositions or duties of myself,

lg.l:
Not liberty—not to cheer up slaves and horrify
despots,
the show of the tushes of power and
